sense.name: land, surface of the earth
sense.commentary: GROUND[+location][+surface][+solid][+land] Note: refers to a place, not soil or dirt (Sense 3) Note: naturally answers the question 'where'
sense.examples: The ground shook violently from the earthquake. All the planes are on the ground due to the ice storm. John dropped the logs on the ground outside the back door of the cabin. They watched the atomic blast several miles away from ground zero.

sense.name: basis, rationale, justification for something
sense.examples: I think we have some grounds for optimism. Critics argued there were not sufficient grounds to warrant an invasion. His theory seems to be on pretty solid ground. They called for a retrial on the grounds of new evidence. But was it grounds for divorce? The two parties could find no common ground during the negotiations.

sense.name: soil substance, dirt, earth
sense.commentary: GROUND[+entity][+substance][+soil] Note: refers to stuff, substance, not a location (Sense 1) Note: naturally answers the question 'what'
sense.examples: The ground is a mass of slippery mud so be careful as you walk. This ground has too much clay to grow good crops. They broke ground for the new hospital at a ceremony this morning.

sense.name: contested territory, a position fought for
sense.examples: Our football team regained some ground during that last play. The patient was losing ground with each round of chemotherapy. The competition has been gaining ground over the past few years.

sense.name: the backdrop of a figure, back area of a visual scene
sense.examples: The red figure is hard to see against that orange ground. I like the picture of Mary in a blue dress set in a ground of wildflowers.

sense.name: an electrical connection between conductor and earth
sense.examples: Run this wire to ground. If there is no ground to this connection, you could get a shock.

sense.name: flat surface prepped for painting or decoration
sense.examples: The painter began sketching in the figures on the ground of his fresco. Her watercolors always start with a white-washed ground.

sense.name: solid particles, e..g., coffee
sense.examples: I dumped the coffee grounds into the trash. The grounds of crushed sea shells sparkled in the yellow sand.

sense.name: primer paint, undercoat
sense.examples: An oil ground must dry completely before applying a latex topcoat. The painters used a latex ground on the house instead of an oil one.

sense.name: property adjoining, surrounding a house, buildings
sense.examples: We strolled across the expansive grounds of the old estate. The man was escorted off the grounds by a security officer. The boys were caught smoking cigarettes on school grounds. (property owned by school)

sense.name: location designated for a specific purpose
sense.examples: A horse broke loose in the parade grounds. The government has closed these fishing grounds indefinitely. These slums have become a breeding ground for terrorists. (metaphoric extension) This bar is a hunting ground for single 20-somethings. (metaphoric extension)

sense.name: area of knowledge, subject matter
sense.examples: The professor covered a lot of ground in today's lecture. Third-year coursed typically cover less ground but go more into depth. He shifted the argument onto theoretical grounds more familiar to physicists.

sense.name: beyond what is necessary or reasonable
sense.examples: Politicians have debated the issue into the ground. Let's don't beat this question into the ground.

sense.name: anew, starting at the beginning
sense.examples: He'll be replacing staff in every department, from the ground up. The architect has totally reworked the building's design from the ground up.

sense.name: to begin, to initiate something
sense.examples: That project never got off the ground. This funding helped get their initiative off the ground.

sense.name: to hide or burrow
sense.examples: The fox went to ground. The robbers made a run for it and probably went to ground somewhere.
